title: The shape of data
body:
Data, it turns out, has shape. That shape has meaning.

The shape of data tells you everything you need to know about your data from its obvious features to its deepest secrets.

This module looks at some of the key methods to discover the shape and characteristics of quantitative (numeric) data including:

  • Averages
  • 5 number summary
  • Distributions and histograms

Interactive exercises will take you through how to use the free Tableau Public tool to examine the shape of data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Filtering and pivot tables
body:
In this module we have seen how simple it can be to analyse data once it is organised in the correct structure. 

If you haven't already, try applying what you have learnt to the course spreadsheet. 

At this point there are two possible directions. Further analysis may be required to find a story; this may require further gathering, organising and cleaning. You may even need to employ further advanced statistical techniques such as the ones outlined in the courses and exercises linked below. Alternatively, you might have discovered your story already and be ready to visualise it. The next stage is choosing the most appropriate visualisation for your data.

Previous module Next module

title: Outliers and robustness
body:
Take the following list of numbers, where two numbers have been added to the list from previously.

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18, 21, 104

We can clearly see that there is now one extreme value in the list (104). This value is commonly referred to as an outlier as it doesn't fit the 'pattern' of the rest of the numbers.

title: The role of data and open data in the policy cycle
displayTitle: The role of data and open data in the policy cycle
body: The policy cycle shown here has three stages: design, implementation and evaluation. Data and open data can play and key role in each stage, some more obvious than others.
instruction: Expand the sections below to discover more about the role data and open data can play in each stage of the cycle.

_items.title: Design
_items.body:
This step defines the structure of the policy and presents possible plans for implementation. 

At this stage data and open data from other sources can be evaluated to effectively inform the design process and provide the evidence.

_items.title: Implementation
_items.body:
Have selected a course of action, it may be less clear what role open data can play. 

However there are many instances where the publication of open data may be the course of action. For instance if the policy is about reducing plastic rubbish pollution, publication of data and statistics will help raise the awareness and potentially lead to behaviour change.

_items.title: Evaluation
_items.body: Similar to the design stage. Data and open data has a key role to play in the evaluation of the success of a policy. Further analysis will help inform us if that policy intervention was successful or not.

title: A biased coin?
body:
A coin is flipped five times with the following results: head, head, tail, head, head.

What can we say about this?

_items.text: The next flip will be tails

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

Random events cluster, when flipping a coin 10 times we should not expect 5 heads and 5 tails every time. Additionally, we should not expect every flip that results in a head to be followed by a tail and visa-versa. 

In this case we also have a very low number of samples, so it is difficult to conclude anything except there were more heads than tails. We cannot in this case say if the coin is biased or not.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Random events cluster, when flipping a coin 10 times we should not expect 5 heads and 5 tails every time. Additionally, we should not expect every flip that results in a head to be followed by a tail and visa-versa.

In this case we also have a very low number of samples, so it is difficult to conclude anything except there were more heads than tails. We cannot in this case say if the coin is biased or not.

title: Public domain licences
body:
Public domain licences allow anyone to use content without any restrictions. Public domain licences are the most permissive and remove all creators' rights over the content. These licences are often selected when the creator recognises that the content will have more value if more people can freely use it.

A good example of this is many of the Google/Alphabet research experiments. After a certain amount of time, each project is reviewed for commercial adoption by Google. If no commercial interest can be seen, then the project is released into the public domain and others can use it without restrictions. For example, the OpenRefine data cleaning tool, introduced in module 6.

title: Summary
body:
Data ethics is a rapidly emerging area. Increasingly, those collecting, sharing and working with data are exploring the ethics of their practices and, in some cases, being forced to confront those ethics in the face of public criticism.

This module looks at the emergence of the area, some of the key case studies and tools to help you be more ethical in your data processing.

Previous module Next Module

title: Visualisation best practice
body:
Visualising data enables us to grasp difficult concepts or identify new patterns quickly.

In this module, we introduce the key tricks that help the eye and brain process and understand data much faster. 

We will cover:

  • Visualisation and the visual cortex
  • Making information pop
  • Using color

title: Benefits of hidden data
body: The problem with downloading data is that you have taken the data away from its source. This means that your copy could now be out of data. Leaving data at its source and using services such as APIs to access this data eliminates this problem and provides other benefits as well.
instruction: Explore the benefits unlocking hidden data can bring below.

_items.body:
In many cases hidden data will be data used by a publisher to present the webpage you are looking at on their site.

The hidden data is therefore an important part of their online operations and it is likely that the publisher takes care over its quality.

Data extracted from the Web tends to be more reliable as it is likely to be data at the core of an organisation's operations. Therefore, it is more likely to be a dependable data source to work with.
_items.title: Quality

_items.body:
Organisations do not always publish downloadable data. However, many of them run data-driven websites. By accessing the data directly through existing data feeds (or from within the website’s code) there is a clear use for the data already. This will help you to quickly identify relevant data from this existing use, rather than having to establish the use yourself. For example, the BBC News pages, sections and related data feeds
Take me to BBC news feeds
_items.title: Relevance

_items.body: When you access data directly from the Web you are already viewing it in a context it is used in by the publisher. As we have covered in previous modules, the context of the data is an important component of its use.
_items.title: Context

_items.body: Often an organisation is limited in the amount of data it can publish as downloadable data. Finding hidden data opens up a broader range of resources.
_items.title: Breadth

title: Statistics: Get the basics rights
body: Like most people, you probably feel that it is important to "take control of your life." But what does this mean? Partly, it means being able to properly evaluate the data and claims that bombard you every day. Statistics are often presented in an effort to add credibility to an argument or advice. If you cannot distinguish good from faulty reasoning, then you are vulnerable to manipulation and to decisions that are not in your best interest. Statistics provides tools that you need in order to react intelligently to information you hear or read. In this sense, statistics is one of the most important things that you can study.

title: A brief history of data visualisation
displayTitle: A brief history of data visualisation
body:
Most charts used in modern data visualisation derive from the original design of William Playfair (1759-1823), a political economist.

William Playfair invented several types of diagrams: in 1786 the line, area and bar chart of economic data, and in 1801 the pie chart and circle graph, used to show part-whole relations.

title: Data in policy making
body:
Policymakers sometimes struggle to see how data can be used to create impact in the world. They know that open data is relevant to the digital economy and building better public services but there are other ways in which data can be used to achieve policy goals. 

This module introduces:

  • The policy cycle
  • The role of data in the policy cycle
  • Case studies in using data in the policy process
  • Policy design patterns

title: Percentages
body:
Last year 60% of people got the answer to this question right. This year 70% get it right.

What increase is this?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

The temptation is to click 10%. A 10% increase on 60 is 66. Thus you can either say this is a "10 percentage point" increase or an increase of 16.6666%.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The temptation is to click 10%. A 10% increase on 60 is 66. Thus you can either say this is a "10 percentage point" increase or an increase of 16.6666%.

title: Test your spreadsheet skills
body:
You can test what you have learned in this module by correcting a messy spreadsheet. 

Download and open this spreadsheet in your favourite spreadsheet application. Then see if you can fix the errors, relating to structure, content and layout, that you learnt about in this module. The spreadsheet contains two sheets of data from the same health facility star-ratings dataset, from different regions in Tanzania.

In order to track your changes on the spreadsheet, you may want to open a new tab or make a new spreadsheet. Create new columns, then add the records from the existing datasets into your new spreadsheet. 

At the point where you have structured your data, you may think it’s ready for processing or even visualising. As discovered earlier in the four step process, this is unfortunately not the case as you need to ensure that your data is of high quality and accuracy.

Previous module Next module

title: Sorting and filtering data
body:
Sorting and filtering data helps you to see trends in the data. 

Before applying any sort or filter operations, make sure that you have frozen the header rows.

Use the video on the right to help guide you.

_items.body:
To sort a column, simply select the column header you want to sort the data by and then select the sort option, normally available from the Data menu or panel in most spreadsheet applications.

You can then choose how you want to sort the data.
_items.title: Sorting data

_items.body:
Filters allow you to limit the data that you see.

To apply a filter, select any cell in your header row and click the filter icon. This is normally available from the same place that the sort function is found.

Once selected, you will notice that your header row gains a dropdown option. Selecting or unselecting the data shown in this dropdown will allow you to both sort and filter the values in a row. This will hide the data, but not get rid of it.
_items.title: Filtering data

title: Visual deception
body:
Visual representations of data vastly decrease the amount of time it takes to communicate a message. However, not all data visualisations are equal. In some cases, a combination of tricks are used to either emphasise a point or, in some cases, mislead the viewer. In this module we look at visual deception in data visualisation and how to avoid it.

In this module we'll explore the following: 

  • Baseline failure
  • Multiple scales
  • Adding depth and area
  • Percentages
  • Area and stacked area charts

title: Correlation and percentages
body: Towards the end of the analysis we might be tempted to use different ways to report findings. Summary statistics might simplify the story, but they might also be misleading. Is a perfect correlation meaningful? Is a 20% increase really a 20% increase? Is the risk of something doubling a big problem?
instruction: Expand the sections below to discover more

_items.title: Correlation
_items.body: Just because there appears to be a correlation, doesn't mean there is one. A famous example from spurious correlations was that banana pricing strongly correlates with number of people who died becoming tangled in their bed sheets. Or the 99% correlation between US spending on space, science and technology and suicides by hanging, strangulation and suffocation.

_items.title: Percentages
_items.body: Percentages can make small numbers look big and are often used this way. For example, last year there was a 100% increase in cancer cases linked to mobile phones. It went from 1 to 2. The other problem with percentages in that many confuse percentage points and percentages. Like in the UK when VAT rose 2.5% from 17.5%. It is at 20% now, but a 2.5% rise would actually make it 17.9375%.

_items.title: Risk
_items.body: Risk is another category to be careful with in statistics. Stating that a risk has doubled, or using percentages, can make the situation appear worse (or better) than it is. Another common pitfall is to not adjust figures for floating variables. e.g. Saying Global cancer incidence predicted to increase by 75 per cent by 2030 is pretty shocking. That is until you realise this percentage has been calculated from the raw numbers of people and has not be adjusted for population growth. Made a good headline though, didn't it?

title: Polish, Publish, Promote!
body: Once you're happy with your draft, take steps to getting your story out there.

_items.body:
Read your draft through fully once more to make sure it is ready to launch.

Make sure all the hyperlinks are correct and link to active webpages, and be sure you have linked relevant content to the side panel if that is possible on the platform you are using to publish.
_items.title: 1. Polish

_items.body:
You should not see publishing your piece as the end of the process, but rather the beginning.

You want the blog to be read by the audience you had in mind when you wrote it, so make sure it is easy for them to find. Keeping Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) in mind when writing your headline is one of the ways in which you can make sure your piece will be visible to people who are interested in the subject of your blog.
_items.title: 2. Publish

_items.body:
Once you have published your piece, be sure to promote it using social media.

If you have quoted or mentioned specific people or organisations in your piece, link to their profiles on social media channels so they are notified and can easily share it. Asking your contacts or relevant organisations to share it across their social media channels can help you to get the widest possible reach.
_items.title: 3. Promote

title: The five components of the perfect open data pitch
displayTitle: The five components of the perfect open data pitch
body:
Creating an effective pitch for open data requires five elements. When brought together, these create a clear, compelling case for action that can be used when seeking management approval, budgetary and resource support and downstream use and reuse. The pitch should be delivered in 90 seconds or less.

The five components of the perfect pitch are:

  1. What it is – the problem you are solving for your users
  2. What it can do – a tailored description of the benefit
  3. Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point
  4. Why it's best – justification for why it beats other options
  5. What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

Below we explore each of these components in more detail.

title: Summary and more reading
body:
One of the key aspects of data analysis is that of spotting trends. Trends give an indication of the direction in which something is changing and can also help us predict what is going to happen next.

But be careful not to overfit or get lost in characteristics of the data that are not significant. 

Even big corporations like Google have fallen into these traps. In 2008 their flu-trends piece of work turned out to be worse at predicting outbreaks of flu than existing techniques. This great lecture from the University of Washington looks at why.

As for classification, we need to be careful with how we build decisions and look for significant factors. Find out more about how the houses data can be used with machine learning algorithms with this fantastic introduction. 

Previous module Next module

title: Q: The role of open data in the policy cycle
displayTitle: The role of open data in the policy cycle
body: In which stages of the policy cycle can open data play a role.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

Data and open data can play a key role in every stage of the policy cycle, some more obvious than others. In the design and evaluation stages, open data can be used to help inform the design and analyse the impact respectively. But releasing open data can also be a part of the implementation, such as the case in all the case studies in this module.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data and open data can play a key role in every stage of the policy cycle, some more obvious than others. In the design and evaluation stages, open data can be used to help inform the design and analyse the impact respectively. But releasing open data can also be a part of the implementation, such as the case in all the case studies in this module.

title: Sampling and hypothesis testing
body: When testing an outcome it is of critical importance to consider the sample that has been take and the significance of the result compared to the null hypothesis, providing that is that the null hypothesis is known?
instruction: Expand the sections below to discover more

_items.title: Sampling
_items.body: It is critical in statistics to select the correct sample to ensure fairness and representation. Sampling incorrectly can lead to incorrect predictions in election results (as happened in the UK in 2015), or suggest that there is a deadly virus sweeping the population, where there isn't. This happened in the UK in 2008 with the norovirus "outbreak". During a two month period 2,000 confirmed cases were reported. From this a ratio of reported and unreported cases of 1:1500 was obtained from the Health Protection Agency. A simple calculation of 2000 x 1500 leads to the conclusion that 3m people had norovirus! What wasn't reported was the confidence in this ratio, which was 5%. To put it another way there is a 95% chance that those 3m people don't have norovirus.

_items.title: Hypothesis testing
_items.body:
Results of experiments will often question the commonly perceived view. For example, scientists have disproved that the correct body temperature is 36.8C not 37C. Is this significant, or are both wrong?

Testing significance to key in hypothesis testing, but can only be done if we know the theoretical model in the first place.

title: Finding downloadable data
body: A lot of data can be simply downloaded through clicking buttons. However, there are still challenges in finding this data in the first place and getting hold of it if there isn't a download button.
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock downloadable data

_items.body:
Many suppliers are helpful and give you human-readable download links in order to obtain their data.

Explore the links below to discover more:

  • data.gov.uk - Land Registry Monthly Property Transaction Data
  • School ranking data in Tanzania
  • School enrolment data in Kenya

_items.body:
Many search engines, including Google, give you the ability to use advanced searches and prefixes in order to dig out data.

Try some of the following search prefixes in Google to see what you can find:

filetype:

Search for specific file types only, eg (xls) (example)

site:

Search with a specific domain or site only (example)

related:

Search for content related to a known page (example)

link:

List only pages that link to the one given (example)
_items.title: Power search for data

_items.body:
Aggregators and portals bring together data from across the Web and expose it through their own service. This creates an easy and consistent way to find and download data.

Explore the links below to find out more:

enigma.io

Transport API

_items.body:
If you can't simply download data in a usable format, you may need to scrape it. There are now many tools to help you achieve this easily:

pdftables.com

Upload a PDF, download data, simple. Try it out with this file.

magic.import.io

Extract data from webpages in a click. Try it on this page.
_items.title: Web scraping

title: What problem are you solving?
body:
You should start your elevator pitch by outlining the problem you are solving for your users: the value proposition.

The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. This is equally relevant in the private and public sectors. Without a strong value proposition, the organisation – whether a large corporation, startup, local authority or charity – does not have justification to keep delivering its services.

Top tip: think of your value proposition as the abstract or executive summary of your solution. Keep it short, keep it snappy and use a list of three.

For example, open data can enhance your business' reputation, improve your customers' experience and diversify your product portfolio.

title: Classification: Try it yourself
body: Try downloading this dataset and following the video to look at your own classification of properties in New York and San Francisco using box plots and scatter plots.

title: Why open data is best
body:
This is the part of your pitch where you can explain your value proposition in more detail. Don't worry about repeating yourself. Repetition is key.

The first time you said your value proposition, you wanted to catch your audience's attention. Now you have their attention, and you've explained the benefits for them, you can explain your solution in more detail.

This is also your chance to justify why your solution is better than the alternatives. You can give competitive examples if relevant, or examples of where data has been shared with positive consequences to emphasise your point. 

Use a list of three for maximum impact, and remember: repetition is key.

title: What open data can do
body:
There are many general arguments for using open data, but a strong pitch needs to be closely tailored to the priorities and concerns of the audience of the pitch and the decision maker.

In most cases, this can be determined from their professional context. Below we examine four common roles, coupled with the most relevant benefits of better use of data.

_items.body: Leaders in an organisation are most likely to be convinced by the arguments that open data can help drive innovation and growth within the organisation, and improve services for users.
_items.title: Leadership

_items.body:
For those in operations roles, reducing costs and being more efficient are priorities. Open data plays a crucial role in resource-saving by enabling a faster exchange of information.

The ability to access, use and share data across multiple platforms and between numerous organisations eradicates the time and cost normally associated with acquiring valuable datasets, one by one.
_items.title: Operations

_items.body: Those in product or marketing roles will respond best to the potential of open data to improve products and services.  More consumers are coming to expect a custom experience, which can be satisfied through greater provision of open data to complement the product function.
_items.title: Product or marketing

_items.body:
For those in communications roles, open data can seem irrelevant to their work. The key message that resonates with communications professionals is that opening data can help to improve the reputation of an organisation. Open data can help to maximise opportunities for media exposure in support of promoting organisational priorities, and complement existing media channels.

As open data is easy to verify, it also increases trust that the article is not 'spun'.
_items.title: Communications

title: What next?
body:
The final element of the pitch is to leave your listener with a clear action.

Listeners want to be able to take action in response to a pitch. Your task is to create an action that allows them to immediately say yes (or no) without needing to think too much about it.

_items.body: Make sure that your listener can respond to your action on the spot. If they need to consult others or consider your action for a while, it is too big. The ideal is an action that is small, clear, and moves the agenda forward.
_items.title: On the spot

_items.body:
Make sure that you set clear expectations for what you are asking. Aspects such as timeframe, resourcing and potential impact should all be central to managing expectations. 

If the listener feels that the timeframe or resourcing constraints limit the opportunity, they may even be able to help. Being open and reasonable will help the listener to become engaged in your pitch.
_items.title: Clear expectations

_items.body: Only ask for budget or time that is reasonable, given the level of expected return. If your requests are unreasonable, you are unlikely to get a positive answer.
_items.title: Reasonable requests

_items.body:
​​​​Good actions don't have to be groundbreaking. Examples of good actions include:

  • getting a date in the diary for a follow-up meeting with more people
  • commitment to read and respond to a case study relevant to their interests
  • commitment to send you a feasibility assessment for your solution
_items.title: Examples of good actions

title: Open data advocacy
body:
Opening data can be valuable for any organisation to make more effective use of their resources. However, most businesses are configured to protect their data resources, even where the benefits of greater sharing outweigh the costs.

Clear, effective communication of the benefits is essential to capture imaginations and gain trust and understanding. In this module, we have learned how to deliver a tailored pitch for open data.

The value proposition is the problem you are solving for your users. The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. This is equally relevant in the public sector.

_items.text: the problem you are solving for your users
an estimate of the value of a solution
how much money you will get

title: Summary
body:
To some numbers can be intimidating. The trick is seeing through them.

Statistics provides tools that you need in order to react intelligently to information you hear or read. In this sense, statistics is one of the most important things that you can study.

From knowing what is being counted to how that sample is representative, being aware of the core concepts of statistics is key to any data analysis.

Previous module Next module

title: Are you ready to communicate your story?
displayTitle: Are you ready to communicate your story?

title: Downloadable and hidden data
body:
Data is not always easy to find on the Web, because most of the available resources are only visible to machines. People navigate the Web visually; viewing content, clicking on links and downloading files.

Machines, by contrast, only navigate the Web through logical rules set out in the code. While humans look for engaging, interactive content, machines require structure, logic and clarity.

This difference creates ‘blind spots’ for how people and machines read the Web. 

Downloadable data is data that is designed for humans to access, for example through a download button. Hidden data is data that is designed for machines to access, for example through structured code.

title: What is hidden data?
body: Hidden data is...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Hidden data is data that is invisible to people as they navigate the Web but that a machine can easily find and understand.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Hidden data is data that is invisible to people as they navigate the Web but that a machine can easily find and understand.

_items.text: data visible to machines but invisible to human eyes
files that are difficult to download

title: How to describe something on a map
displayTitle: How to describe something on a map
body: There are many parts to a map and cartography can become an art. This section briefly looks at the many layers of a map.

_items.body:
Points help you precisely locate something on a map, for example, a person or a place. 

Often these are used to mark the middle of an object that might often be better represented by another map feature, such as a line or polygon.
_items.title: Points

_items.body:
Lines represent the shape and location of geographic objects, such as street centre lines, rivers or ferry routes.

Lines are also used to represent features that have length but no area, such as contour lines and boundaries.
_items.title: Lines

_items.body:
Polygons are complete shapes that represent a feature such as regions (as shown here) or buildings.

They can also be used to represent land-use or even soil type. 

Using GIS software, you can automatically calculate which points are in which polygon. This is often used to shade areas on a map dependant on the data collected from many points, e.g. the performance of schools in a region.
_items.title: Polygons

_items.body:
Bringing all these features together allows us to create powerful maps that accurately show the layout and features of a huge area.

The example here of the centre of Dar Es Salaam is one of the most comprehensive examples in the world. This data was gathered as part of the Ramani Huria project and shows roads (lines), buildings (polygons), building use (points) and annotations that describe each point.
_items.title: Bringing it all together

title: Multiple scales
body:
Another common method used to emphasise a difference or correlation is to use multiple scales. 

Typically, this involves having different scales on each side of the chart that each relate to different plots of data. 

The example shown here from the Colorado Department of Transport uses two scales to try and emphasise how different fatal accidents are in 2016 compared to previous years. 

Things to note:

  • The scale on the right does not start at zero (baseline failure)
  • The intervals on the two scales are different
  • The coloured bars for other years are not always for the same years (i.e. green is not always 2010)

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Which 3 steps do you need to take when planning your story?
displayTitle: Which 3 steps do you need to take when planning your story?
body: There are 3 steps you need to take when planning a story. These are...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Before you start drafting your story, make sure that you know what structure the story will take, that you have the right resources (including data visualisation and any research), and have a catchy headline.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Before you start drafting your story, make sure that you know what structure the story will take, that you have the right resources (including data visualisation and any research), and have a catchy headline.

_items.text: Setting the structure, gathering resources, drafting the headline
Setting the structure, drafting the headline, making it up
Drafting the story, adding a title, adding pictures

title: Drafting your story
body:
Once you have written your summary and gathered your resources, you should be well prepared to draft your story. If you think you don't have enough resources to write what is detailed in your summary, either return to gathering resources or tweak the summary to fit with what you know. Once you have finished, read through your draft and check it for the things that will make it engaging, accessible and accurate.

This checklist will help you make sure your blog is well-structured. Ask yourself:

_items.strapline: Does my draft have a clear beginning, middle and end?
_items.body:
Think of your storyline as taking the shape of an arc.

Begin simply by setting the scene - what is the main takeaway of the article?

Then build up your story. Towards the end of the article, the reader should have all the information they need.

The ending hammers home the main takeaway of the story again, bringing together the main points covered throughout the article.
_items.title: Does my draft have a clear beginning, middle and end?

_items.strapline: Does my headline fit onto two lines?
_items.body:
Five times as many people will read the headline, as will read the rest of the article.

Ask yourself, 'what will make people want to read more?', and keep it short and snappy.
_items.title: Does my headline fit onto two lines?

_items.strapline: Does my draft include URL links (or footnotes)?
_items.body:
Make sure you can substantiate your claims by pointing to the data and attributing where you can. 

Linking your publication to other websites and resources will also increase your story's exposure on the web.
_items.title: Does my draft include URL links (or footnotes)?

_items.strapline: Is there a call to action?
_items.body:
What do you want your readers do differently after reading the piece?

Whether your goal is to educate or inspire, motivate or amuse, make sure that you point towards the right resources for your readers to take action.
_items.title: Is there a call to action?

title: Area and stacked area charts
body: Perhaps one of the most confusing charts ever created. Introducing area, stacked area and the stream graph.

_items.body:
Area charts are great for showing a single value that may consist of many parts. However if being used to compare two or more sets of values they should be avoided. 

Why? 

Because when the human brain looks at an area chart it sees mountains. Which means that one set of values is behind the other. 

This is correct for an area graph, so why should you not use them? Click to the next section to find out...
_items.title: Area charts

_items.body:
The stacked area chart looks exactly the same as an area chart. However the two sets of values are now on top of each other not behind one another.

How do you tell?

There is no way for sure to tell what you are looking at unless it is stated. 

Take a look at both examples here as they use exactly the same set of source data. Can you tell the difference?
_items.title: Stacked area charts

_items.body:
Going one step further and introducing the stream graph.

Is this stacked or an area chart? 

Where is the zero value on the y-axis?

Is the order of items significant?

Abandon all hope!
_items.title: Stream graphs

title: Open data advocacy
body:
Opening data can be valuable for any organisation. Whether to drive innovation in the business, develop a clearer picture of operations or improve products and services, a growing number of private and public sector organisations now benefit from publishing and using open data.

However, opening data might require a change in the culture of an organisation. Most organisations are configured to protect their data resources, even when the benefits of openness outweigh the costs. The key to overcoming this resistance is clear: effective communication of the benefits that open data can bring.

This module will prepare you to deliver a tailored pitch for open data that highlights value and addresses risks.

In this module we'll explore how to:

  • Structure the perfect pitch
  • Identify different audiences for your pitch
  • Tailor your pitch to different audiences

_graphic.attribution: Tanzania dLab [All rights reserved]

title: Classification: Dealing with noise
body:
Not all characteristics are going to help easily classify something. For example eye colour does not help classify types of bird and certainly wouldn't be the first characteristic you would consider. The same is true in any data and classification. It is important to find out which aspects are those that will help perform the most effective classification. 

With data, a scatter plot (as shown here) can be used to plot each characteristic against every other. Doing this, patterns may start to appear that separate one type of thing (e.g. a bird) from another.

The scatter plot here looks at characteristics of houses in two different cities (represented by colour). It is clear to see from these plots that the characteristics that differentiate the two cities most are "elevation" and "price per sqft".

title: Classification
body:
Classification is another type of predictive analysis. Classification is a process related to categorisation, the process in which ideas and objects are recognised, differentiated, and understood. 

A typical example is that of identifying a bird. There are thousands of species and variants of species, thus a novice twitcher (bird watcher) is unlikely to be able to identify the exact species by will use characteristics like size, colour and call in order to perhaps get the correct family of bird (e.g. gull). 

The same can be done with data and indicators. In the commerce industry, people's buying habits are often used to classify them into a certain demographic of customer that helps the industry target it's marketing better.

title: Summary
body:
Policymakers sometimes struggle to see how data can be used to create impact in the world. The policy cycle is a useful tool that can help guide the complex process of driving or delivering that change.

Data and open data are core to delivering change throughout every stage of the policy making process where open data isn't just an input for analysis but also an output that delivers transparency and accountability for everyone. 

Effective use of data in the policy process can also deliver broader benefits and a better data infrastructure for society to build upon. 

Next module

title: Header rows and the freeze function
displayTitle: Header rows and the freeze function
body:
The freeze function is useful when viewing, managing and organising large datasets. It 'freezes' the column titles at the top of the page, so you can always check your value against the associated row and column, without scrolling back up to the top. 

This function can be accessed from the 'View' menu of most spreadsheet applications.

title: The box-and-whisker plot
body:
The box-and-whisker plot is a way to visually show the location, spread and range of the data using the five-number summary, as shown.

The whiskers show the minimum and maximum values and thus show the range of the data.

The box is plotted between the lower and upper quartiles. The box shows the interquartile range (IQR) or middle 50% and is the most significant basic robust measure of scale.

The size of the IQR boxes also show the spread of the data, with a smaller box representing a smaller spread and vice-versa.

title: A four step approach to storytelling with data
displayTitle: A four step approach to storytelling with data
body:
There are many stages and challenges in using data to inform policy. A modern policy advisor working with data may be expected to undertake (or at least understand) many - if not all - of the stages.

In this module we will introduce:

  • The four step data storytelling process
  • Components of the four step process
  • Planning your time

title: Data analysis
body:
Which spreadsheet tool is essential for generating powerful summary statistics of a raw dataset? 

The same tool can also rotate the data to reveal new patterns in the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Pivot tables are a powerful data summary. Among other functions, a pivot table can automatically sort, count, total or give the average of the data stored in one table or spreadsheet. The results are displayed in a second table.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Pivot tables are a powerful data summary. Among other functions, a pivot table can automatically sort, count, total or give the average of the data stored in one table or spreadsheet. The results are displayed in a second table.

title: The distribution of data
body:
Another important aspect to consider is the distribution of data. It is always a good practice to know the distribution as certain analyses require certain distributions.

The examples here show different types of distributions of data.

_items.title: Normal distribution
_items.body:
A normal distribution (or bell curve) is a symmetrical distribution where the mean, median and mode are all very similar (or the same).

Many things closely follow a Normal Distribution:

  • heights of people
  • errors in measurements
  • blood pressure
  • marks on a test

_items.title: Negatively (left) skewed
_items.body:
A negatively skewed distribution is influenced by outliers at the lower end of the data's range. This means that the mean would be less than the median and mode. It seems counterintuitive that the majority of the data is on the higher side, but it is called negative skew. 

Examples of negatively skewed data include:

  • Retirement age
  • Book prices
  • Age of death (in developed countries)

_items.title: Positively (right) skewed
_items.body:
A positively skewed distribution is influenced by outliers at the higher end of the data's range. In this case, the mean is greater than the mode or median.

Examples of positively skewed data include:

  • Capital project costs
  • Household income
  • Property prices

_items.title: Non-normal (jumbled up) data
_items.body:
Data with a non-normal distribution can occur. 

There are still pieces of analysis that can be performed on the data, but these are different from the distributions covered in this module.

Examples include:

  • Cost of healthcare
  • Crime rate data

title: Adding depth and area
body: The first thing that the brain notices when looking at a visualisation is the size of different parts.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.body:
Adding 3D effects increases the area of a graph. To the human brain the perceived size is now larger with the additional volume. 

Providing that the volume is equal in all cases then this is fine (e.g. the volume of an area with value 4 is exactly twice the volume of an area with value 2). 

However, if the volumes are not proportional, or as is the case here potentially infinite, then it can be difficult to grasp real values.
_items.title: Adding depth

_items.body:
Removing the 3D infinite depth shows a different view of the data. 

With the depth removed, previously large changes are no longer present in the data. 

Interestingly, this data also suffers from the fact that the figures have not been adjusted for inflation. Adjusting the figures shows that state expenditure had not changed in real terms for the previous seven years.
_items.title: Removing depth

_items.body:
Using raw values as the radius of a circle is another big mistake. 

The easy way to spot this mistake is to attempt to fit a smaller circle inside a bigger circle. For example, a circle representing the value '1' should fit in another circle representing the value '3' exactly three times. 

As can be seen in the example here, this is not the case. Smaller differences seem bigger, due to the incorrect scaling of the circles.
_items.title: Radius and area

mobileInstruction: Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

title: Averages
body:
Not all averages are the same. 

Often "average" refers to the arithmetic mean, the sum of the numbers divided by how many numbers are being averaged. When analysing data it is important to understand the difference between mean, median, and mode.

_items.title: Mean
_items.body:
The most common type of average is the arithmetic mean.

The arithmetic mean, often simply called the mean, is calculated by adding up all the numbers in a list and dividing by the number of items in the list.

For example take the following list of numbers:

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18

The sum of the number is 70, there are 7 items in the list. Therefor the mean is 10 (70 / 7).

_items.title: Median
_items.body:
The median is middle number of the list where the numbers are ranked in order. 

For example take the following list of numbers that are already ranked in ascending order:

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18

There are 7 numbers, the middle number will be the 4th one in the list. Therefor the median of this list of numbers is 10.

_items.title: Mode
_items.body:
The mode is the most frequently occurring number in the list. 

Taking our list of numbers:

3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18

The most frequently occurring number is 13.

It may happen that there are two or more numbers which occur equally often and more often than any other number. In this case there is no agreed definition of mode. Some say they are all modes and some say there is no mode.

title: Counting, numbers and chance
body: Essential to all statistical methods is the understanding of how things are counted and what these numbers mean once they are collected. Further we need to be aware of outliers and random chance that will affect all experiments.
instruction: Expand the sections below to discover more

_items.title: Counting
_items.body:
Counting is hard. Especially when the definition of what is being counted in not clear.

For example, counting the number of boats in the picture here...

Are there 9? Or are there 0 as none are boats they are canoes... or kayaks... who knows?

The boundaries are not always clear in all cases, so the statistics might not be either.

_items.title: Big and small numbers
_items.body:
Numbers can be big or small, but sometimes a small number can be big and a big number can be small.

It is important to think about the environment and context that each number applies to before coming to conclusions.

For example a score of 10 (out of 10) is a big score, but £3m for the health service split between the population of the UK is 4.5p each.

_items.title: Chance
_items.body: Random events cluster, when flipping a coin 10 times we should not expect 5 heads and 5 tails every time. Additionally, we should not expect every flip that results in a head to be followed by a tail and visa-versa.

title: Maps
body:
Many datasets are related in some way to locations, and so visualising data on a map is the perfect way to make the data come to life. Care should be taken in creating the right type of map, and using the right features to direct the reader. For example, a map showing population across a large area should use a choropleth map. A map plotting 1000 densely clustered points would probably be better as a heat map, as the regions will be less defined and the grid size would be smaller. You can read further about the difference between the two maps here. 

The example shown on the right details all the empty and unused building in Detroit. Having the map showing all buildings is essential.

Aaron Koblin's flight patterns is a good example of a spatial visualisation that doesn't require an underlying map layer.

title: Visualisation essentials
body:
Communicating impact from data is a key skill of any modern data worker. This module has introduced some of the essential techniques that can help effectively visualise data.

Choosing the correct visualisation is the first step, but it does not guarantee that it will lead to an effective story. The visualisation will require careful design in order to make the story clear to the audience as we explore in the next module.

Previous module Next module

title: Essential charts
body: Knowing which chart to use when communicating your story is essential to creating the right impact.

_items.body:
The human brain is very good at quickly judging the size of simple shapes, such as rectangles. Thus the bar chart can very effectively communicate differences. 

Simple bar charts can communicate powerful messages quickly. Enhancing bar charts and pie charts with graphics and well placed text can also aid clear understanding. You do not even always need scales or lines.

The picture on the left compares the revenue of one product to the revenue of an entire company, where the product has made more money. If you were creating a visualisation which told this story, what might you add to make this finding stand out even more?
_items.title: Bar charts

_items.strapline: Team GB Medal Olympic medal count comparison
_items.body:
Line and area charts should only be used where there is a time series to be displayed. In most countries and cultures, people read left to right. Therefore, line charts must be constructed to be read from left to right. 

A line chart, as shown here, is best for comparing multiple sets of data over the same (or equivalent) timeframe.

An area chart can be used to emphasise the totals. When using area charts, it is best to use a stacked area to clearly show the total of all datasets over the same (or equivalent) period of time.
_items.title: Line and area charts

_items.body:
Histograms should be used when a set of samples are taken at different points in time. For example, exam grades of different people or different heights, as shown here. 

A histogram is perfect for showing graphically where the median and mode lie. They also show the distribution (or shape) of the data and surface any outliers that might skew the location of the mean. 

Significantly, they can reveal whether the samples in your dataset are normally distributed, or contain data that might be skewed or falsified.
_items.title: Histograms

title: Exploring large datasets
body:
You have a dataset containing the grades of students attending every school in the country in a single sheet. Your dataset is over 100,000 rows in length. 

If you want to look at only the results from a single school, what should you do?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

With all the data in one sheet, you can use filters to quickly look at any custom selection of the data. While it might seem logical to split data of this size into several sheets, the instant ability to analyse all the data is lost.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

With all the data in one sheet, you can use filters to quickly look at any custom selection of the data. While it might seem logical to split data of this size into several sheets, the instant ability to analyse all the data is lost.

_items.text: Sort the dataset and scroll to find the school
Change the way that the data is collected such that the data about each school is in a separate sheet
Use a filter to show only the data for that sheet
Manually create a new sheet with the data in

title: Mapping open data
body:
This module explores digital maps and how open data can enhance them; how to use maps in projects; and how to visualise and explore data with them. By the end of the module, you'll have a good understanding of the issues around digital mapping, and skills that can be used in your own work.

The module explores:

  • Introduction to digital maps
  • Benefits of open mapping
  • How to describe something on a map
  • Formats and standards
  • Practical mapping with CartoDB

title: Introduction to digital mapping
body:
Digital maps and the associated Geographic Information Systems (GIS) enable us to easily capture, manipulate, analyse and present spatial and geographic data. 

Geographic data here refers to any data that has an implicit or explicit association with a location. Typically, this covers a wide range of data, including positional data (e.g. locations of schools), boundary data (e.g. regions of Tanzania) and elevation data (e.g. the height of Kilimanjaro). 

Maps have for centuries been critical to helping us to understand where we are and what is around us. Digital maps go beyond this and allow us to create new data visualisations for any dataset that has a geographic connection. Digital maps can help to inform decisions that we need to make, for example...

title: What is trend analysis?
body:
Trend analysis is a type of predictive analysis similar to (and often called regression analysis). It uses existing or historical data to try and predict what might happen in the future.

One of the best examples of trend analysis is in credit scoring, used throughout financial services. This type of analysis looks at a customers financial history and gives a score to indicate their likelihood of making future credit payments on time. 

As we have seen in the previous module, we need to be careful how predictive analysis is applied due to factors like fluctuation. Some data may look like it will trend when it fact it doesn't and might have a different shape.

Before moving on why not try to predict where the trend will end up if another 10 points are added to the graph shown here. A,B,C or D?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Summary
body:
Data, it turns out, has shape. That shape has meaning.

The shape of data tells you everything you need to know about your data from its obvious features to its deepest secrets.

This module looked at some of the key methods to discover the shape and characteristics of quantitative (numeric) data including:

  • Averages
  • 5 number summary
  • Distributions and histograms

By the end of this module you should be confident in unlocking the shape of data. 

Previous module Next module

title: The five-number summary
body:
The five-number summary provides a concise summary of the distribution of numeric data. The five-number summary gives information about the location, spread and range of the data.

The five-number summary consists of the following:

  1. the sample minimum (smallest value)
  2. the lower quartile (value ¼ through the list)
  3. the median (middle value in the list)
  4. the upper quartile (value ¾ through the list)
  5. the sample maximum (largest value)

_items.title: Example
_items.body:
Taking our 9 number list (3, 5, 8, 10, 13, 13, 18, 21, 104), the five-number summary would be as follows:

  1. Minimum: 3
  2. Lower quartile: 6.5 (half way between 5 and 8)
  3. Median: 13
  4. Upper quartile: 19.5 (half way between 18 and 21)
  5. Maximum: 104

title: Are you ready to clean data?
displayTitle: Are you ready to clean data?
body: Can you recall the reasons why data needs to be cleaned, the useful tools to use and which common errors you should look for in datasets?

title: What do we mean by clean data?
displayTitle: What do we mean by clean data?
body:
Knowing that your data is clean is important to ensure you have a reliable starting point when using a dataset and creating new value from it.

Clean data is data that is consistent, free from duplication and ready for machine consumption.

If data is clean, it is easier to combine with different datasets and find deeper insights.

title: Have you been deceived?
body:
Visualisations should always be constructed to represent a true picture of the data. In communicating your message, make sure to avoid misleading your viewers. 

This module looked at the key techniques used and examined how to avoid being deceived. 

Why not test your knowledge further, and examine extra examples at viz.wtf?

You may have created an engaging visualisation, but your audience might still struggle to understand the story without additional explanation or narrative.

Previous module Next module

title: Policy design patterns
body: Data can help improve government policy. As data becomes ever more abundant and useful infrastructure for our societies, then data will only help more. To help recognise the benefits of data to policymakers, the ODI developed a series of design patterns to help government policy makers see how data could be used to create impact.
instruction: Expand the sections below to find out more about each design pattern

_items.title: Improved consumer experience
_items.body:
These interventions create better lives for citizens, in particular but not limited to their interactions with state service provision.

One example is providing open detailed mapping data to everyone. This can be used from everything from finding a bus stop, to helping with community city planning efforts for flood resilience.

_items.title: Efficient delivery
_items.body:
These interventions make service provision or the fulfilment of regulatory requirements by government more efficient and effective.

Typical examples include the regulation and bench marking of public service provision (such as schools) to identify weaknesses and drive improvements.

_items.title: Market interventions
_items.body:
These interventions focus on making data available in order to correct for market failures, such as by breaking down monopolies, surfacing externalities and promoting competition.

Typical examples include the publishing of pay gap data, plastic bag usage and other datasets to drive behaviour change.

_items.title: Better data management
_items.body:
These interventions help government more effectively and efficiently manage the data that it relies on, and with wider societal and economic benefits.

Typical examples include the authoritative publication of country wide data, such as list of registered and official schools. The publication is a driver for better management and increased quality of the data.

_items.title: Better policy making
_items.body:
These interventions focus on making it possible for government to make better policy in the long term.

Typical examples include to use of data to evaluate the effectiveness of government itself.

title: Fluctuation
body:
The graph here show the number of accidents on a road for each month in a year. 

Which of the following represent valid predictions of where the accident rate might be after the following year?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

Random events fluctuate, thus a pattern that suggests an increase won't always mean that this trend will continue forever. This is particularly the case for things like road accidents. We will never get to a road where every car will have an accident every minute of the day. Equally it is unlikely the figure will ever be zero.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Random events fluctuate, thus a pattern that suggests an increase won't always mean that this trend will continue forever. This is particularly the case for things like road accidents. We will never get to a road where every car will have an accident every minute of the day. Equally it is unlikely the figure will ever be zero.

title: Case studies in using data in the policy process
displayTitle: Case studies in using data in the policy process

_items.title: Waste collection in Mexico
_items.body:
In Xalapa, waste collection was frustrating the public as there was no clarity on how the service operated. It was not clear when or where the rubbish was collected from. 

The municipal government intervened by fitting a GPS tracker to the collection trucks and releasing the live locations as open data. This led to the design of new routes and to citizens developing their own app to help people solve the problem. 

You can read more about this case study and others in Mexico here.

_items.title: Improving flood resilience in Tanzania
_items.body: Ramani Huria is a community-based mapping project that began in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, training university students and local community members to create highly accurate maps of the most flood-prone areas of the city. As the maps have taken shape – their benefits have multiplied and their potential magnified, now serving as foundational tools for development within all socio-economic spheres beyond flood resilience.

_items.title: Providing a better fire service in London
_items.body:
In 2013 the London Fire Brigade was faced with a tough decision to close 10 fire stations in order to save money while providing the same level of service. A thorough and open approach to the data analysis led to an effective decision being taken that meant that not only did the closures have no significant impact, but the redistribution of fire engines to remaining stations has actually improved the service in many areas.  

The ODI developed a tool to help examine the potential impact. This uses open data from the London Fire Brigade and you can find out more here.
_items.strapline: Providing a better fire service in London

title: Summary
body:
Data increases in value the more it can be understood and shared.

In addition to a visualisation, build a shareable story around it and disseminate that story widely for maximum impact. 

So when you’ve found a great story, make sure you tell it in a way that’s clear, relatable, and impactful.

A modern data scientist is expected to be a catalyst for change in an organisation. Creating compelling stories is an essential skill for those who want to truly have impact. Remember that the first module looked at some great examples of how a great story can come from data. 

Previous module Home

title: Choosing the right format
body:
Stories come in many different shapes and sizes. When you want to communicate a story, you need to decide how you want to share it and who you want your audience to be.

It may be that your data story is part of a wider bit of research. In this case, you might want to write a detailed book about it. However, books are a huge time investment, and will only be read by those who are already interested in your specialist subject. To maximise your impact and reach, your story needs to be easily shareable, searchable and succinct. 

This module will focus on writing compelling online articles and blogs to share your findings, give context to your visualisations and tell your story. 

Many different businesses and organisations now invest in blogging as an agile form of communicating ideas, projects and news to the wider world. When they are well structured and engaging they can attract widespread readership and help raise the organisation's profile. On the other hand, if they are not well structured, they can put people off and even pose a risk to the organisation's reputation.

title: Story narration in 2 minutes
body: Writer Anna Scott introduces why and how you should add narrative to your story.

title: Gathering data
body:
Data plays a key role in storytelling, however not all data is easy to find.

The growing demand for data has led to an increase in human friendly data services, including data portals and simple download buttons. However, downloadable data represents only a small fraction of the available data on the Web. The majority of data available on the Web is hidden from the human eye. But machines can find and read this data.

In this module we explore the following: 

  • The difference between downloadable and hidden data
  • Finding downloadable data
  • Finding hidden data
  • The benefits of using hidden data

title: Pivot tables
body:
A pivot table is a powerful data summary tool found in all spreadsheet tools. Among other functions, a pivot table can automatically sort, count, total or give the average of the data stored in one table or spreadsheet, displaying the results in a second table.

Pivot tables also give you the ability to "Pivot" or rotate the data, changing the column and row labels used from the original dataset. 

The example video demonstrates how to create a simple pivot table that gives the total number of health facilities per star rating. Here, the star ratings are used as the row labels and we have one column of data that represents the total count of facilities for each rating. 

Try following this through with your own dataset.

title: Fast formula
body:
In your spreadsheet of school marks you want to find the highest mark achieved by any student. 

Which formula do you require?
instruction: Select one answer and then click 'submit'

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

To quickly find the highest mark you need the =MAX() formula.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

To quickly find the highest mark you need the =MAX() formula.

title: Formula and statistics
body:
Spreadsheet applications have powerful formula functions to help you analyse the data. Here we are going to look at few of the simple formulas. 

This is where we will use the separate sheet in our spreadsheet for statistics. This means we will avoid including unnecessary tables in with our dataset or limiting the ability to add additional rows. All the formula used means that you can still add data to the original sheet and the statistics will automatically update in the second sheet. 

Again, you can use the video to help guide you.

_items.body:
Calculating averages is a common operation with any numeric data. But remember, there is more than one type of average!

In the statistics sheet of the spreadsheet, we want to find out the mean and mode star ratings. These can be added by using the AVERAGE() and MODE() formula on the star rating column. 

To calculate the AVERAGE() star rating, type the following formula into the correct cell in the statistics sheet and then follow the instruction in italics. 

=AVERAGE( click Star Rating column in data sheet )
_items.title: Averages

_items.body:
To find out what the lowest and highest star ratings are, you can use the MIN() and MAX() formula. 

e.g. 

=MAX( click Star Rating column in data sheet )
_items.title: Lowest and highest values

_items.body:
The COUNT() and COUNTA() functions help to count how many items there are in a large sheet. 

COUNT() and COUNTA() are two very similar functions. The difference between them is that COUNT() only counts cells containing numbers but COUNTA() counts all cells that aren't empty, meaning it will also count cells with text or other characters.

You can obtain the count of star rated facilities using the following formula. 

=COUNT( click Star Rating column in data sheet )
_items.title: Count the number of items

title: Creating a dashboard in Tableau
body: If you have completed the above exercise on one of the datasets then you should now be able to create an interactive dashboard in Tableau. The video below shows you how to do this from the result of using the "average heights" dataset (dataset 3).

title: Component title
body:
The following table compares the averages from the previous list to this new list:

 Previous listNew listChange
Mean1021+11
Median1013+3
Mode13130

We can see here that the mean is badly affected by outliers, thus the mean is the least robust average. The median has medium robustness and the mode is the most robust with no change.

title: Are you ready to legally work with data?
displayTitle: Are you ready to legally work with data?
body: Understanding your rights as a user is essential; do you know if you are using data correctly?

title: Components of the four step process
displayTitle: Components of the four step process
body: This course has been specifically designed to look at the entire process of using data to tell stories. Explore the components below to get an overview on how the course fits together.

_items.body:
In order to use data, you first need to have the data. 

Finding data can be easy, if you know where to look. However the web also contains a lot of hidden data. Find out more in the gathering data module. 

When you are gathering data, is it important to understand your legal rights to use the data. The next module covers some of the key legal information you need to know.
_items.title: 1. Gathering data

_items.body:
The four step process outlined above assumes that once you have data, you can immediately start filtering and using it. 

There are however several steps preceding the filtering of data:

Organising data

Data is likely to be gathered from many sources and it will be necessary to organise the data in a consistent way for analysis. 

Cleaning data

As you start to organise the data you are likely to note errors or inconsistencies in the data that require fixing. 

Filtering data

Once you have a usable dataset, it is finally possible to start filtering the data to find your story.
_items.title: 2. Filtering data

_items.body:
Once you have analysed the data, the next step is to visualise the data to highlight significant findings.

When it comes to visualising data, you need to consider three things:

Format: Which visualisation should you choose?

Clarity: Does the visualisation tell your story?

Intrigue: Does the visualisation engage or deceive?
_items.title: 3. Visualising data

_items.body:
In order to maximise impact of your story, you need a strong narrative which can relate to the desired audience at the right time. 

Find out more on writing your own narrative with the final module of this course.
_items.title: 4. Telling a story

body:
Dataset 1

The salaries of the New York Bulls soccer team.

The salaries of the Manchester City football team.
